case_vignette: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. He also has had a loss of sensitivity around his buttocks and inner thighs as well as increased trouble urinating the last week. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was treated with radiation therapy. Neurologic examination shows reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; the right side is normal. The resting anal sphincter tone is normal but the squeeze tone is reduced.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having sharp, stabbing pain in my lower back that spreads to the back of my left leg for the past two weeks.
Do you have any tingling or numbness in your leg or foot?
Yes, I've lost some feeling around my buttocks and inner thighs.
Do you have any weakness in your leg or foot?
Yes, my left leg is weaker than usual.
Have you experienced any recent trauma or injury to your back or leg?
No, I haven't had any recent trauma or injury to my back or leg.
Do you have a history of diabetes or any other medical conditions?
I was diagnosed with prostate cancer two years ago and was treated with radiation therapy.
Do you have a family history of neurological conditions or back problems?
I don't know of any family history of neurological conditions or back problems.
**Final Diagnosis:** Lumbar disc herniation with radiculopathy
